JPSartre12

Boy fights for right to play on girls team Lawsuit will affect field hockey at Forsythe 
 Thursday, September 22, 2005
 BY NATHAN FENNO 
 News Sports Reporter 
 A few minutes after practice started Wednesday afternoon, Maxime Goovaerts ran onto the field and joined the rest of Forsythe Middle School's girls field hockey team. 
 But behind the happy chatter of another practice, a legal battle is being waged over whether the 13-year-old boy can play on a girls team. 
 Nathalie Vandecan, Goovaerts' mother, sued Ann Arbor Public Schools last Friday, alleging violations of Michigan's Elliott-Larsen Civil Rights Act. The lawsuit accuses Ann Arbor Public Schools, among other things, of denying Goovaerts "the full utilization and benefit of services, opportunities, activities and programs provided by (the) Defendant because of his sex.'' 
 On Wednesday morning, the parties reached an agreement allowing Goovaerts to play while the case is pending in court. That hasn't changed the status of the lawsuit or the Ann Arbor Public Schools' view that boys shouldn't play on girls teams. 
 "We're pretty strong in our position that this is a girls sport,'' said George Fornero, Ann Arbor schools superintendent. "We don't want to get in a situation where we take up slots with boys for girls teams or the boys physically dominate the girls out there.'' 
 Goovaerts played for the girls team at Forsythe last year. But, Vandecan said, Ann Arbor school officials told her earlier this month that her son couldn't play this year because the school had to remain in compliance with Title IX, the landmark 1972 federal legislation that requires equal educational opportunities for male and female students. Forsythe doesn't have a boys field hockey team. 
 Vandecan sat in the shade and watched practice alone Wednesday, pleased that her son was back on the field, but uncertain of what is ahead. 
 "I'm just cautious,'' Vandecan said. "I'm excited, but I'm scared, too, of the unknown.'' 
 After the court order spelling out the agreement was signed, Fornero said the district hasn't changed its position. 
 Vandecan said her son, who has also dabbled in soccer and golf and is interested in figure skating, learned field hockey from one of her nephews. Goovaerts is about 5 feet tall and weighs 100 pounds, smaller than some of the girls on the field hockey team. 
 "He is thus certainly not a danger on the field,'' Vandecan wrote in an e-mail to Fornero. 
 No players are cut from the team, Vandecan said. In the e-mail, she wrote that Goovaerts wouldn't play if it meant keeping a girl off the team. 
 Fornero said he wasn't aware of any other boys on girls teams in the district. Fornero said he allowed Goovaerts to play last season because the decision to keep boys off girls teams was made after the season started. 
 "There was a significant reaction when they played other teams,'' Fornero said. "Parents said, 'We could have a winning team if we put boys on our teams.' We changed the rules midseason. The coach at that school (Forsythe) had not put the word out.'' 
 Vandecan's attorney, Marla Linderman, cited a similar case that occurred in Traverse City in 1987, when the Michigan Civil Rights Commission told the Traverse Area Public School District to let boys play on girls volleyball teams after a challenge by an eighth-grader. The district later had to pay a girls volleyball coach $43,600 because it had fired her for letting boys on the team. The district spent $160,484 fighting the case. 
 Goovaerts and his family are originally from Belgium and have lived in Ann Arbor for five years. Vandecan said her son was "very excited'' when she stopped by Forsythe and told him he'd be able to play Wednesday. 
 But the lawsuit looms over the sunny field behind the school that was filled with swinging hockey sticks and the cries of children Wednesday. 
 "They think they're using Title IX,'' Linderman said of Ann Arbor Public Schools. "They don't understand the law.''

 What about the racial difference? Very little whites and asians play football. Why not have a black team, white team, and an asian team? I understand your point but why not apply it to other things?
 
 What about basketball? Being short is a genetic disadvantage just as gender is. So why not have height teams. You have the 6' and over team, the 5'6" and over team or in smaller intervals.
 
 We have a kid who is not short but not tall either at our school. He tried out for the original school team and got cut. Every single day for 2 hours after school he shoots, does drills, runs suicides, and a bunch of stuff to get better at basketball. He plays basketball with friends after school. He asked the coach what he needed to do to make the team next year, any suggestions for drills or anything. The suggestion was "get taller". People were over a foot taller than him and he has no hope of playing. But he continues to practice all afternoon as people are going home. If I were the coach I would take him on my team just because of the work ethic and the hope he would inspire others even if he doesn't play a minute. But the coach is more worried about fancy stuff and dunks and such. I haven't seen this guy play much other than in the gym on my way out of school but apparently he is one of the best players in terms of machanics, conditioning, and work ethic. Why shouldn't he be the best player on the 5'8" and up team? Yes you complain about how girls wouldn't play, what about short people? What about white people? What about black people in terms of baseball?
 
 I'm not claiming I have the answer and I have to say that in general I would think there should be equal opportunity and no girls on boys teams or vice versa, but I also don't think it's fair that another genetic difference, height, can make that much difference, or something like race. Why is the gender genetic difference the only one recognized? I don't know, maybe other people have other thoughts.

 Let me pose this scenario then - 
 
 50 men try out for the men's field hockey team, but the team has a maximum roster size of 20 players. So 30 players are cut, and the men's roster is full. 
 
 The women's field hockey team also has a maxiumum roster size of 20 players. All 30 men that tried out for the men's team and got cut show up at the women's try outs. Why not, it's equal opportunity right? Turns out that 19 of those men are better than all but 1 woman. So the "women's" field hockey team now consists of 19 men and 1 woman. 
 
 Does that make sense to you?
 
 You might say, simply increase the roster size, well then, how do you determine who plays during the games?
 
 Any rules you make specific to man vs. woman are essentially the same thing as separating the teams by sex.
 
 No matter how you look at it, it just doesn't make sense in any kind of a competetive environment, let alone a professional one.

No, but this one clearly is. Look at who lines up on what side of this issue and tell me that it isn't liberal vs conservative. emoticon_rolleyes 

 
 HEY! I think we agree here and I am a liberal.
 
 
Tell me if this is a conservative or liberal speaking:

 
 No clue. An over-zealous idiot????
 
 You think conservatives aren't capable of backing unfair positions or saying dumb-XXX stuff? There are ijuts everywhere.
tonybrown74

Let me pose this scenario then - 
 
 50 men try out for the men's field hockey team, but the team has a maximum roster size of 20 players. So 30 players are cut, and the men's roster is full. 
 
 The women's field hockey team also has a maxiumum roster size of 20 players. All 30 men that tried out for the men's team and got cut show up at the women's try outs. Why not, it's equal opportunity right? Turns out that 19 of those men are better than all but 1 woman. So the "women's" field hockey team now consists of 19 men and 1 woman. 
 
 Does that make sense to you?
 
 You might say, simply increase the roster size, well then, how do you determine who plays during the games?
 
 Any rules you make specific to man vs. woman are essentially the same thing as separating the teams by sex.
 
 No matter how you look at it, it just doesn't make sense in any kind of a competetive environment, let alone a professional one.
 
 Waxy

 
 I don't think I have pointed out anywhere in that post that I was for a quota system for sports. 
 
 The reality is that there were women interested in playing sports and, not only was there not an opportunity for them to play, but that mens sports received far more money and support than women's sports. 
 
 Competition is another issue altogether.
JPSartre12

I don't think I have pointed out anywhere in that post that I was for a quota system for sports. 
 
 The reality is that there were women interested in playing sports and, not only was there not an opportunity for them to play, but that mens sports received far more money and support than women's sports. 

 
 Men's sports are usually a money-making proposition. Few women's sport teams actually generate revenues for their schools. It's no wonder that schools prefer to put their efforts into men's teams. It's a purely economic decision...Now whether or not college sports should be about making money is a topic for another thread. 
 

 Competition is another issue altogether.

 
 As is competition for $$$. :)

It's a purely economic decision...Now whether or not college sports should be about making money is a topic for another thread. 

 
 I think we are mixing the two issues again. Let me restate what I meant:
 
 I believe that Title IX is a remedy for equal access to athletics, not necessarily competition.
 
 
 
As is competition for $$$. :)

 
 In most instances, yes.
zachvac

One of my buddy's daughters wrestled for our high school and did quite well, actually. She started as a gymnast when she was ~5 and was always very strong for her size. When she graduated HS, she became a Marine. And if you ever saw her in her wedding dress, you'd know that she was no "tomboy", either. My point: there are exceptions to the rule.

 
 Just as long as you know they are exceptions. There are 2 white guys on our football team too.
Ooaman

I think there is a question tht was thought of but never addressed.
 Does the school only have a female hocky team? Does the male student not have a chance at a male hocky team because there isn't a male team? If this is the case, then why has there never been any male team started?
 
 Oh and for the record, there are some cases where some women would be stronger than some guys. If a guy is not physically fit at all, then any woman can be stronger than him. The only thing that would make it dangerous for a woman in some cases no matter how much stronger she was, would be if the bigger, out of shape (other than round) guy falls on her.

 It's possible that they had a male team. The university that gave us our last winning men's Olympic gymnastics team no longer has a men's gymnastics program.
